articles.title: Nepal gets first female PM after deadly unrest
articles.summary: Former Supreme Court chief justice Sushila Karki is sworn in after a deal with protest leaders.
articles.content:
Nepal gets first female PM after deadly unrest

The ban was lifted on Monday - but by then protests had swelled into a mass movement. Angry crowds set fire to parliament and government buildings in the capital Kathmandu on Tuesday , forcing Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli to resign.

More than 50 people were killed in clashes with riot police during this week's mass protests sparked by a ban on social media platforms.

Karki, 73, was sworn in during a brief ceremony, becoming the first woman to lead the impoverished Himalayan nation after a deal was reached with the protest leaders.

Nepal's former Supreme Court chief justice Sushila Karki has become the country's interim prime minister after deadly anti-corruption protests ousted the government.

Fire and smoke rise from the Singha Durbar palace, which houses government and parliament buildings, as protesters stormed the premises in Kathmandu

Earlier on Friday, President Ram Chandra Poudel's press adviser confirmed to the BBC that Karki would take the oath of office in the evening.

The agreement between the president and the protest leaders was reached after days of consultations. Legal experts were also involved.

Parliament was dissolved late on Friday and it was announced that general elections would be held on 5 March next year.

Karki is expected to appoint ministers in her cabinet within a few days.

She is widely regarded as a person of clean image, and is being supported by student leaders from the so-called "Gen Z" to lead the interim government.

Her cabinet will face multiple challenges - restoring law and order, reconstructing parliament and other key buildings that were attacked, as well as reassuring the Gen Z protesters who want change - and others in Nepal who are fearful its young democracy and constitutional order could be derailed.

Another key task will be to bring those responsible for violence to justice.

Karki's appointment is a result of compromise in the talks this week that were brokered by Nepal's army chief. Elated Gen Z supporters are expressing their happiness on social media and many see this as the next step in the new political course they want the country to take.

On Tuesday, Karki visited the protest site in Kathmandu where 19 people were killed in clashes with police the day before. She also met some of the injured who were being treated in hospital.

Karki was born in a family with close contacts with the Koirala political dynasty from the country's largest democratic party Nepali Congress, and later married the then leader party Durga Subedi.

She has said that her husband's support played a major role in her journey from a lawyer to Nepal's chief justice in 2016.

But Karki has not been free from controversy, having even faced an impeachment incident during her nearly 11-month tenure as chief justice.

Nepal's army is still patrolling the streets of Kathmandu, as the country reels from its worst unrest in decades. Restrictions were only briefly lifted to allow residents to buy essential items.

The protests were triggered by the government's decision last week to ban 26 social media platforms, including WhatsApp, Instagram and Facebook - but they soon widened to embody much deeper discontent with Nepal's political elite.

In the weeks before the ban, a "nepo kid" campaign, spotlighting the lavish lifestyles of politicians' children and allegations of corruption, had taken off on social media.

And while the social media ban was hastily lifted on Monday night, the protests had by that stage gained unstoppable momentum.
articles.reasoning: The article reports the historic appointment of Nepal's first female prime minister following mass protests against corruption and political unrest. This event represents a significant political breakthrough with broad societal impact, symbolizing progress in democratic governance, gender equality, and accountability in Nepal. The story contains sufficient context about the protests, political compromise, and challenges ahead, highlighting a hopeful political transition.
articles.personality_title: Nepal swears in first female prime minister after major protests

The ban sparked anger, leading to violent clashes in the capital, Kathmandu, with over 50 people killed. Protesters also set fire to government buildings, causing Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli to resign.

**What happened** – On Friday, Sushila Karki, a former chief justice, was sworn in as Nepal's first female prime minister. This followed a deal between protest leaders, the president, and Nepal’s army chief to form an interim government. Parliament was dissolved, and new elections are scheduled for March 5 next year. Karki is expected to soon choose her cabinet.

**Impact** – Karki’s appointment is historic because she is the first woman to lead Nepal, a country with a young democracy facing serious political challenges. Known for her clean image, she has the support of younger protesters who want change. Her government will need to restore order, repair damaged buildings, and hold those responsible for violence accountable.

**What’s next step** – Karki will form her cabinet and start governing as Nepal prepares for elections. Her leadership will be tested by the need to unite the country, respond to protesters’ demands, and rebuild trust in the political system.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Nepal’s first female prime minister takes office after mass protests, marking a new chapter in the country’s political life with hopes for reform and stability.

articles.title: General Assembly endorses New York Declaration on two-State solution between Israel and Palestine
articles.summary: Applause rang out in the UN General Assembly Hall on Friday as countries endorsed a declaration on the peaceful settlement of the question of Palestine and implementation of the two-State solution with Israel.
articles.content:
The New York Declaration is the outcome of an international conference held in July at UN Headquarters, organized by France and Saudi Arabia, which resumes later this month.

The General Assembly comprises all 193 UN Member States and 142 countries voted in favour of a resolution backing the document.

Tweet URL

Israel voted against it, alongside nine other countries – Argentina, Hungary, Micronesia, Nauru, Palau, Papua New Guinea, Paraguay, Tonga and the United States – while 12 nations abstained.

‘Roadmap’ for the future

Prior to the vote, French Ambassador Jérôme Bonnafont recalled that the New York Declaration “lays out a single roadmap to deliver the two-State solution”.

This involves an immediate ceasefire in Gaza, release of all hostages held there, and the establishment of a Palestinian State that is both viable and sovereign.

The roadmap further calls for the disarmament of Hamas and its exclusion from governance in Gaza, normalization between Israel and the Arab countries, as well as collective security guarantees.

Speaking ahead of the vote, Israeli Ambassador Danny Danon said that “this one-sided Declaration will not be remembered as a step toward peace, only as another hollow gesture that weakens this Assembly’s credibility.”

He said that “Hamas is the biggest winner of any endorsement here today” and will declare it “the fruit of 7 October”.

The high-level international conference in July was held against the backdrop of the war in Gaza and deteriorating prospects for the two-State solution.

In remarks to the opening segment, UN Secretary-General António Guterres noted that “the central question for Middle East peace is implementation of the two-State solution, where two independent, sovereign, democratic States – Israel and Palestine – live side-by-side in peace and security.”

The article provides sufficient context about the declaration's content, voting details, and the broader peace roadmap.
articles.personality_title: UN General Assembly backs New York Declaration for Israel-Palestine peace plan
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The conflict between Israel and Palestine has lasted many years, with efforts to find peace often facing setbacks. The idea of a two-State solution means creating two independent countries, Israel and Palestine, living side by side in peace and security. In July, an international conference at the United Nations (UN) in New York worked on a plan called the New York Declaration to support this goal.

**What happened** – On a recent Friday, the UN General Assembly, which includes all 193 member countries, voted on whether to support the New York Declaration. A large majority, 142 countries, voted in favor of it. Ten countries, including Israel and the United States, voted against it, and 12 countries chose not to vote. The declaration calls for an immediate stop to fighting in Gaza, the release of hostages, the creation of a Palestinian state that can govern itself, and the disarmament of the group Hamas.

**Impact** – This vote is important because it shows strong international support for a clear plan to bring peace between Israel and Palestine. The declaration is seen as a ‘roadmap’ that outlines specific steps to reduce violence and build trust. It also encourages better relationships between Israel and other Arab countries. Although some countries disagree with the plan, the wide support means there is a strong push for peaceful solutions at the global level.

**What's next step** – The New York Declaration will continue to be discussed and worked on during upcoming meetings. Countries and leaders will try to follow the steps in the plan, like stopping the fighting and working toward a Palestinian state. The success of this plan will depend on cooperation from all sides and ongoing international support.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN General Assembly’s strong backing of the New York Declaration marks a key diplomatic move toward peaceful coexistence between Israel and Palestine through a two-State solution.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’Assemblée générale de l’ONU approuve la Déclaration de New York pour la paix entre Israël et la Palestine
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le conflit entre Israël et la Palestine dure depuis de nombreuses années, avec de nombreuses tentatives de paix souvent difficiles. La solution à deux États consiste à créer deux pays indépendants, Israël et la Palestine, vivant côte à côte en paix et en sécurité. En juillet, une conférence internationale aux Nations Unies (ONU) à New York a préparé un plan appelé Déclaration de New York pour soutenir cet objectif.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Un vendredi récent, l’Assemblée générale de l’ONU, qui réunit les 193 pays membres, a voté pour soutenir la Déclaration de New York. Une grande majorité, 142 pays, ont voté en faveur. Dix pays, dont Israël et les États-Unis, ont voté contre, et 12 se sont abstenus. La déclaration demande un arrêt immédiat des combats à Gaza, la libération des otages, la création d’un État palestinien capable de s’autogérer, et le désarmement du groupe Hamas.

**Impact** – Ce vote est important car il montre un large soutien international à un plan clair pour la paix entre Israël et la Palestine. La déclaration est vue comme une « feuille de route » qui détaille des étapes précises pour réduire la violence et instaurer la confiance. Elle encourage aussi de meilleures relations entre Israël et d’autres pays arabes. Malgré des désaccords, ce large soutien représente une forte volonté mondiale pour des solutions pacifiques.

**Prochaine étape** – La Déclaration de New York sera encore discutée lors des prochaines réunions. Les pays et dirigeants essaieront de suivre les étapes du plan, comme arrêter les combats et avancer vers un État palestinien. Le succès dépendra de la coopération de tous et du soutien international continu.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Le fort soutien de l’Assemblée générale de l’ONU à la Déclaration de New York représente une étape diplomatique clé vers la coexistence pacifique entre Israël et la Palestine grâce à la solution à deux États.
articles.personality_title_es: La Asamblea General de la ONU respalda la Declaración de Nueva York para un plan de paz entre Israel y Palestina

Diez países, incluyendo Israel y Estados Unidos, votaron en contra, y 12 se abstuvieron. La declaración pide un alto inmediato a los combates en Gaza, la liberación de rehenes, la creación de un estado palestino que pueda gobernarse por sí mismo, y el desarme del grupo Hamas.

**Impacto** – Esta votación es importante porque muestra un fuerte apoyo internacional a un plan claro para lograr la paz entre Israel y Palestina. La declaración es vista como una ‘hoja de ruta’ que detalla pasos concretos para reducir la violencia y construir confianza. También fomenta mejores relaciones entre Israel y otros países árabes. **Resumen en una frase** – El fuerte respaldo de la Asamblea General de la ONU a la Declaración de Nueva York representa un paso diplomático clave hacia la convivencia pacífica entre Israel y Palestina mediante una solución de dos Estados.

articles.title: Gonzato: The EU will continue to support strengthening the independence, accountability, and efficiency of the judiciary in Albania
articles.summary: "We will continue to assist the KLP with our best expertise to help Albania meet EU standards," Gonzato stated.
articles.content:
“We will continue to assist the KLP with our best expertise to help Albania meet EU standards,” Gonzato stated.

The European Union Delegation in Tirana will closely follow the process of selecting the new head of the special structure against organized crime and corruption.

The EU Ambassador to Albania, Silvio Gonzato, held a meeting with the Chairwoman of the High Council of the Prosecution, Mirela Bogdani, from which he conveyed the message that the EU delegation will also continue to support the entire judicial system in strengthening independence, accountability, and efficiency at all levels.

The High Council of the Prosecution is one of the new bodies of judicial governance, resulting from the Justice Reform.

“A trustworthy and independent justice system remains essential to strengthen citizens’ trust and to advance Albania’s path towards the European Union,” Gonzato stated.

During the meeting with Bogdani, Gonzato discussed future work and key moments expected, including the selection and appointment of the new head of SPAK.

Gonzato declared that the EU delegation will closely follow this process as well as continue support for the Justice system.

The HCP has a crucial role in ensuring transparent and merit-based procedures for appointments, evaluations, and professional standards within the prosecution system.

“We will continue to assist the HCP with our best expertise to help Albania meet EU standards,” Gonzato expressed.

The Special Prosecution against Corruption and Organized Crime (SPAK), as an entity resulting from the Justice Reform, has played a role in advancing Albania’s integration agenda by tackling impunity at various levels.

After a week, the HCP will begin the process of selecting the new head of SPAK who will succeed Altin Dumani in office.

Three years ago, Dumani received the majority of votes from the HCP, 5 out of 11 present at the meeting. (September 11)

The article provides sufficient context about the judicial reform and the role of key institutions like SPAK and HCP.
articles.personality_title: EU pledges continued support to strengthen Albania’s judicial system
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Albania has been working to improve its justice system through a reform aimed at making courts and prosecutors more independent, fair, and effective. A special group called SPAK was created to fight organized crime and corruption. The High Council of the Prosecution (HCP) helps manage this system by choosing leaders and setting professional rules.

**What happened** – The European Union’s Ambassador to Albania, Silvio Gonzato, met with Mirela Bogdani, the Chairwoman of the HCP. He assured that the EU will keep helping Albania improve its justice system to meet EU standards. The EU will also closely watch the selection of the new head of SPAK, who will take over from the current leader, Altin Dumani. This selection process is important to ensure fairness and transparency.

**Impact** – This support from the EU is important because it helps Albania build a justice system that people can trust. A strong, independent judicial system means crimes like corruption and organized crime are more likely to be punished. This also helps Albania move closer to joining the European Union by meeting its requirements.

**What's next step** – In about a week, the HCP will start choosing the new leader of SPAK. The EU will continue to provide advice and monitor the process, making sure it follows clear and fair rules. This ongoing cooperation aims to improve the justice system even more over time.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU remains committed to helping Albania build a fair and effective justice system by supporting key institutions and overseeing important leadership appointments.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’UE promet un soutien continu pour renforcer le système judiciaire albanais
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Albanie travaille à améliorer son système judiciaire grâce à une réforme visant à rendre les tribunaux et les procureurs plus indépendants, justes et efficaces. Un groupe spécial appelé SPAK a été créé pour lutter contre le crime organisé et la corruption. Le Haut Conseil de la Poursuite (HCP) gère ce système en choisissant les dirigeants et en définissant les règles professionnelles.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – L’ambassadeur de l’Union européenne en Albanie, Silvio Gonzato, a rencontré Mirela Bogdani, présidente du HCP. Il a assuré que l’UE continuerait à aider l’Albanie à améliorer son système judiciaire pour respecter les normes européennes. L’UE suivra également de près la sélection du nouveau chef de SPAK, qui succédera à Altin Dumani. Ce processus est important pour garantir l’équité et la transparence.

**Impact** – Ce soutien de l’UE est important car il aide l’Albanie à construire un système judiciaire digne de confiance. Un système judiciaire fort et indépendant signifie que des crimes comme la corruption et le crime organisé sont plus susceptibles d’être punis. Cela aide aussi l’Albanie à se rapprocher de l’Union européenne en respectant ses exigences.

**Prochaine étape** – Dans environ une semaine, le HCP commencera à choisir le nouveau chef de SPAK. L’UE continuera à fournir des conseils et à surveiller le processus pour s’assurer qu’il suit des règles claires et justes. Cette coopération vise à améliorer encore le système judiciaire.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’UE reste engagée à aider l’Albanie à construire un système judiciaire juste et efficace en soutenant les institutions clés et en supervisant les nominations importantes.
